repnme.cdata!:
Cambodia - Agricultural Productivity
            Improvement ; Northeast Village Development ; Forest
            Concession Management and Control ; and Flood Emergency Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The principal ratings for the Cambodia
            Agricultural Productivity Improvement; Northeast Village
            Development; Forest Concession Management and Control; and
            Flood Emergency Projects are as follows: the outcome was
            moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was significant, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the borrower performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory. Some of the lessons learned from the project
            include the following: in the future, the use of learning
            instrument loans (LILs) or any instrument that circumvents
            any of the usual safeguard investigation during preparation
            should be subject not only to the normal tests of
            eligibility, but also the test o f downside risks, be these
            technical or the likelihood of adverse public opinion; where
            the client is not familiar with Bank operations and
            procedures or is confronting serious impediments to its
            ability to act on that knowledge, continuous presence of
            competent Bank representatives is a critical factor in
            moving dialogue and operations forward; when ambiguity or
            disagreements arise in implementation, particularly with the
            evolving focus or importance of an activity, an agreed
            strategy can become an effective management tool;
            institutions generally respond more favorably to moderate or
            gradual change than to radical innovation, particularly when
            power or stature are being threatened; and finally, while
            fiduciary accountability requires correct procedures and
            oversight, the development impact o f the Bank's
            approach to the issue is very much linked to the sensitivity
            with which it introduces the qualities of transparency and
            cost-effectiveness as desirable qualities in procurement transactions.

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Agriculture
            Productivity Improvement Project (APIP) were as follows:
            outcomes were unsatisfactory, sustainability was unlikely,
            the institutional development impact was modest, the Bank
            performance was unsatisfactory, and the borrower performance
            was unsatisfactory. From the implementation experience of
            the project, a number of lessons can be drawn with
            applicability in Cambodia and a wider context: (a) the
            special circumstances of Cambodia in the early 1990s i.e. a
            country whose human resource base and public sector
            apparatus had been severely damaged must be taken into
            account in any attempt to understand the rationale for
            project design and the idiosyncrasies of project
            implementation; (b) sustainability can be achieved only if
            there is ownership within the institutions and interest on
            the part of the key players; (c) in order to fill a void,
            three elements of sub-sectoral strategy were identified to
            be designed during the early years of the project and five
            were added at the Mid-term Review and these have been
            valuable in assisting the government and in encouraging an
            informed dialogue between the government and donors; (d) it
            is essential that preparatory work (e.g., base-line studies)
            and system design should be done as part of project
            preparation and that the monitoring system should function
            from the beginning of a project; (e) where components were
            implemented by Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and
            Fisheries Departments, there tended to be a
            "double" management structure and, hence, from
            early in the project emphasis was given to the
            "main-streaming" of APIP into the regular
            structure of MAFF Department; (f) complex procedures
            concerning the approval of expenditures that had already
            been agreed to in annual work plans caused significant
            delays, compounded by delays in the release of counterpart
            funds; and (g) as a result of its complexity, with nine
            components and eighteen sub-components, the IDA budget for
            supervision was consistently inadequate to include the
            required technical expertise in every supervision mission,
            and as a result, some components could not receive
            appropriate technical guidance.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Agricultural Productivity
            Improvement Project's overall objective is the
            sustainable and broad-based improvement of small holder
            agricultural productivity as a means to improved food
            security and increased rural incomes.  The project will
            comprise the following nine components addressing priority
            development needs of the Ministry of Agriculture Forestry
            and Fisheries (MAFF): a) agronomy, seeds and plant
            protection; b) animal health and production; c) agricultural
            hydraulics; d) fisheries; e) small holder rubber research;
            f) human resource management; g) support to provincial
            departments of agriculture; h) planning and statistics
            strengthening; and i) establishment of a Project Management
            Unit (PMU).
